thread.title: WA election 2017: Both Labor and Liberal decline to rule out preference deal with One Nation - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)
thread.title_full: WA election 2017: Both Labor and Liberal decline to rule out preference deal with One Nation - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)

author: Jacob Kagi
title: WA election 2017: Both Labor and Liberal decline to rule out preference deal with One Nation - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)
text:
Wed Feb 01 19:22:46 EST 2017 Photo Mark McGowan faced questions about One Nation while launching Labor's official election campaign. ABC News: Jessica Strutt 
The Labor and Liberal parties have labelled controversial comments about single mothers by a One Nation candidate as "offensive and rude", but both have declined to rule out striking a preference deal with the party ahead of the March state election. 
"His comments were offensive and rude and I think they were totally inappropriate," he said. 
Liberal Deputy Premier Liza Harvey said Mr Archibald should rethink his comments. 
"I'm a single mum myself and I've got to say, it's bloody hard sometimes being a single parent and he should perhaps one day have a walk in the shoes of a single mum or a single dad and rethink his comments," she said. 
Deputy Prime Minister and federal Nationals leader Barnaby Joyce also waded into the issue, saying he does not agree with Mr Archibald. 
"Don't start suggesting to someone, all the nuances of their life, and think you understand them. Empathy is probably a better approach. Find on what's going on in their life and see what you can do to help," he said. Labor, Liberal decline to rule out One Nation preference deal 
Mr McGowan would not be drawn on how Labor would handle preferences with One Nation. 
"You can talk to the party about those issues, those sorts of issues I am not going to talk about today," he said. 
Figures from both major parties showed One Nation could play a substantial role in the state election, with polling suggesting its popularity had surged in recent months.
